case_title: Sardar REHMATULLAH KHAN vs AZAD GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF JAMMU AND KASHMIR through its Chief Secretary
court: Azad Jammu and Kashmir Service Tribunal
respondant: Azad Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir through its Chief Secretary

accussed_details.name: Sardar REHMATULLAH KHAN
allegation: Misappropriation of foodgrain in the Food Department
Failure to prevent embezzlement under his administrative control

complaint_summary: The appellant was retired from service under Section 12(ii) of the Civil Servants Act, 1976 without being charge-sheeted or given an opportunity to defend himself. He alleged mala fide action and violation of Islamic injunctions.
investigation_summary: Reports from the Chief Secretary and Inspection Team exonerated the appellant from involvement in misappropriation cases. However, the retirement decision was influenced by external factors and motivated complaints.
judgment_summary: The tribunal found the retirement order to be a colorable exercise of power and without jurisdiction. The appellant was reinstated with back benefits and deemed retired upon reaching the age of superannuation.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted; retirement order quashed; appellant reinstated with back benefits.
legal_arguments: Provisions of Section 12(ii) of Civil Servants Act, 1976 are violative of Islamic injunctions.
Retirement was unjustified given the appellant's meritorious service record.
Mala fide allegations must be proven.
Government's discretion under Section 12(ii) does not require show-cause notice or inquiry.
citations: P L D 1986 S C (A J & K) 87
Raja Muhammad Niaz Khan v. Azad Jammu & Kashmir Government
Muhammad Akramullah v. Secretary Establishment Division, 1984 P L C 360
Federation of Pakistan v. Saeed Ahmad Khan, P L D 1974 S C 151
Ghous Muhammad Shah v. Province of Punjab, 1984 P L C 1539
Federation of Pakistan v. Nazir Ahmad Swati, 1986 S C M R 2001
key_issues: Validity of retirement under Section 12(ii) of Civil Servants Act, 1976
Mala fide action by the appointing authority
key_findings: Appellant was retired without being charge-sheeted or given an opportunity to defend himself.
Reports from the Chief Secretary and Inspection Team exonerated the appellant from allegations of misappropriation.
Retirement was deemed a colorable exercise of power influenced by external factors and not based on service record.
Appellant's service record was largely unblemished, with positive assessments from senior officials.

legal_terms.mala fide: Bad faith or intent to deceive
legal_terms.colorable exercise of power: Use of authority in a deceptive or improper manner

words_and_phrases.retirement simplicitor: Retirement without any formal charges or inquiry
words_and_phrases.public interest: Action taken for the welfare or benefit of the public

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the premature retirement of Sardar Rehmatullah Khan under Section 12(ii) of the Civil Servants Act, 1976. The tribunal found the retirement order unjustified and influenced by external factors, despite the appellant's exoneration in official reports. The appellant was reinstated with back benefits.

legal_basis.challenged_law: Section 12(ii) of the Civil Servants Act, 1976
issues_raised: Mala fide or colorable exercise of power

decision.action_taken: Order of retirement and Review Petition rejected by the Government are set aside.
decision.outcome: Appellant reinstated with back benefits and deemed retired upon reaching the age of superannuation.
